results.title: 3 good reasons
results.brief_description: David Hunt is a volunteer for the Heart Foundation. He speaks of his own personal tragedies and how these particular events have motivated him to dedicate his time to the Heart Foundation. Made as part of ‘The Heart of the Story’ in association with Vic Health and the Heart Foundation.

results.title: 3 dances - Gulpilil
results.creator_credit: David Roberts, Tom Manefield, Commonwealth Department of Aboriginal Affairs and Film Australia
results.brief_description: David Gulpilil performs three Aboriginal dances, Emu, Kangaroo and Fish. The first two are solo performances by Gulpilil and are closer to mime than dance. The third is a group dance with some of the children from Bamyili where Gulpilil lives in the Northern Territory.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Roberts, Tom Manefield, Commonwealth Department of Aboriginal Affairs and Film Australia

results.title: 28 degrees above below
results.creator_credit: Ken Page, Bane Jovanovic, David Bairstow and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Twenty-eight degrees above zero was the temperature below the sea ice, although surface temperature dipped to 50 below at Resolute Bay within the Arctic Circle when the MacInnis Expedition made its first organised winter dive in the polar sea to test the ability of man and his equipment to function in that extremely hostile environment. Commenting on the expedition is Dr. Joseph B. MacInnis himself, in brief conversation with astronaut Scott Carpenter. There is underwater footage of the dive and of Sub-Igloo, the plastic spherical habitat which was anchored to the ocean floor. (Awards: Milan)

results.title: 28 days later = twenty eight days later
results.creator_credit: Danny Boyle, Andrew Macdonald, Film Council, DNA (Korea) and Fox Searchlight Pictures
results.brief_description: Upon waking after being in a coma for 28 days, bicycle courier Jim (Cillian Murphy) finds a completely different world. London is empty except for the virally infected zombies that want to murder everyone - and there aren’t many people left. Jim is rescued by Selena (Naomie Harris) who proves to be a strong and fearless survivor. The virus is passed on through blood and devastates within seconds, driving the infected into a murderous rage that essentially threatens human existence. But is the virus all that endangers the survivors? End-of-the-world survival tale done in a dark and sombre mood - a science-fiction horror story from the director of “Trainspotting” and “The Beach”, Danny Boyle. Cast includes Christopher Eccleston, Megan Burns and Brendan Gleeson. SOME SCENES MAY DISTURB.

results.title: 26 times in a row
results.creator_credit: Jacques Bobet, Jean-Claude Labrecque and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The Marathon has become a symbol of the Olympics. A modern-day addition to the Games, it commemorates the soldier who ran cross-country, in 490 B.C., to announce the Greek victory at Marathon and then died. Excellent film footage of the 1976 Olympic Marathon documents the physical demands of the race. Its emotional counterpart is related by Cierpinski, the event’s 1976 gold medalist. This emotion-charged film proves that although the winner of the Decathlon is the best all-round athlete, the “toughest” is the winner of the Marathon. (Award: Portland)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jacques Bobet, Jean-Claude Labrecque and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: 250 million years ago: permian life in Australia
results.creator_credit: Lex Halliday, Harold Fletcher and Australian Museum
results.brief_description: The permian deposits found most notably in the Kimberley’s, North-West Basin and the Hunter Valley are some of the world’s richest fossil deposits. Mostly marine, but some fresh-water and land strata fossils are included. Typical fossils such as butterfly shells, starfish, lace coral, as well as plants and coal seams are highlighted.

results.title: 1914 - 1918 The Great War and the Shaping of a Century
results.creator_credit: Carol Sennett, Carl Byker and BBC
results.brief_description: This is a seven part series from the BBC looking at the Great War and the shaping of a century through the words of those who endured it. The series is narrated by Dame Judy Dench. The first part, Explosion, contains the first three episodes and details the build up to the War and the first years of the campaign. The second part, Legacy, expplores the War and the consequences of the end of the War, including the Treaty of Versailles and the seeds that were sown for the second World War.

results.title: 21-87 (D)
results.creator_credit: Arthur Lipsett, Colin Low, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A wry comment on the machine-dominated man, the man to whom nothing matters, who waits on chance for his number to come up. An experimental film presenting a succession of many unrelated views of passing crowds - church, in the street, in the circus. The effect is chaotic, but true to life. (Awards: Chicago, Ann Arbor, Palo Alta.)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Arthur Lipsett, Colin Low, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: 1914-1918 : legacy
results.creator_credit: Margaret Koval, Imperial War Museum (Great Britain), BBC-TV and KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “1914 - 1918 The Great War and the Shaping of a Century”.
1914-1918 is a seven part series from the BBC, looking at the Great War and the shaping of a century through the words of those who endured it. With the use of many letters, diaries and film we re-experience a war that involved the people of 5 continents. Narrated by Dame Judi Dench, we also hear voice-overs by Ian Richardson, Martin Landau, Wendy Craig, Tim Pigott-Smith, Chris Fairbank, Jeremy Irons, Liam Neeson, Tom Fleming, John Shrapnel, Malcolm McDowell and Imogen Stubbs reading passages from personal diaries and letters. Many historians including Dr Jay Winter provide valuable background information relating to battles and events which occurred both before, during and after, what became known as The Great War. Tape Two-Legacy contains the last four episodes of this remarkable series. Episode 4-SLAUGHTER, the battles of Verdun, the Somme and Passchendaele were three of the worst of the war, yet soldiers sought to keep their sanity with music, sport and theatre. Episode 5-MUTINY, by the start of 1917, the strain of war was affecting people on the home and battle fronts. Half of the French army mutinied. Episode 6- COLLAPSE, Germany’s war effort collapsed in 1918. Episode 7-LEGACY, the end of WW1 did little to relieve suffering across Europe. Four empires collapsed and large parts of the continent were devastated. The Peace Treaty of Versailles did nothing to ease the suffering of either the conquered or victorious people, and the seeds were sown for a second war. This was a war of attrition of men, machines and ideals. The futility of losing a generation of 9 million men who never came home, from a war many didn’t understand. National honour, fervour, and man’s greed to expand borders and dominate others led to a society which was torn asunder and would never be the same again. It affected and influenced art, music, literature and changed the history for the rest of the 20th Century.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Margaret Koval, Imperial War Museum (Great Britain), BBC-TV and KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.)
